header.title: The Deadly Secrets of Dim Mak Vital Point Striking
header.category: Esoteric Martial Arts / Vital Point Striking

central_thesis: The book aims to reveal the closely guarded secrets of Dim Mak, a Chinese martial art technique involving vital point striking to incapacitate, injure, or kill an opponent, while also noting its potential for healing. It emphasizes the practical application and training methods for these techniques, stressing responsibility and ethical use.

structure_content.summary: Introduces Dim Mak as a closely guarded secret, including the 'Death Touch' anecdote, and positions the report as an addition to martial arts curricula. It disclaims responsibility for misuse, advises professional instruction, and highlights that Dim Mak points are effective but should only be used for self-preservation or healing.

Explains the motivation for sharing this previously secret knowledge. It notes the intentional omission of some lethal 'Chi Striking' elements, which are reserved for highly ethical individuals via direct instruction. The text likens Dim Mak to a weapon, advocating responsible teaching, and states its true secret lies in preserving health and life rather than causing death.

Positions Scientific Premium Company as a pioneer in openly teaching Chi Power and Pressure Point techniques since 1980. It contextualizes Dim Mak as an ancient 'Death Point Striking' technology, a high-level martial art originating in China and spreading to other cultures. The text acknowledges variations in point systems and mentions historical animal testing to confirm efficacy.

Describes that Dim Mak strikes vary in their inflicted damage and effectiveness based on training and point location. It details three categories: Tien Ching (attacking nerves), Tien Hsueh (striking blood vessels), and Tien Hsing Chi (attacking Chi Meridians). The chapter also broadly outlines the vital points' role within a comprehensive self-defense curriculum.

Focuses on inducing paralysis by striking nerves throughout the body. The method is presented as effective even without pinpoint accuracy, as nerves are accessible and responsive to strikes, gauging, twisting, and poking. Practical self-experimentation is suggested to understand pain responses.

structure_content.chapter_title: Some People Will Not Respond / Big Muscles, Big Target
structure_content.summary: Identifies factors affecting a person's response to nerve strikes: high pain threshold (physical/mental condition), anatomical variations in nerve density/location, and subcutaneous fat. It notes that muscular individuals often have nerves closer to the skin, making them easier targets for precise strikes that leverage technique over brute strength.

structure_content.chapter_title: Level Two: Tien Hsueh (Striking Blood Vessels)
structure_content.summary: Describes this advanced method involving sealing blood vessels to cause clots, organ deterioration, cardiac arrest, or stroke. This technique often requires internal 'chi striking' and precise knowledge of optimal striking times (time of day). Due to its complexity, detailed instruction is offered directly by SPC-USA.

structure_content.chapter_title: Level Three: Tien Hsing Chi (Attacking Chi Meridians)
structure_content.summary: Details the highest level of Dim Mak, aiming for immediate or delayed death by altering the body's electromagnetic chi flow and destroying its energy levels. This method necessitates the ability to externalize chi, referencing 'Chi Power Plus and Advanced Chi Video' for more information, and is noted as a highly dangerous practice.

Acknowledges differing opinions on the exact number of vital points but affirms all points in the course diagrams are Dim Mak points. Effects of correct strikes include bleeding, fainting, paralysis, organ damage, and death. It disclaims personal use for death but cites ancient acupressure, animal, and prisoner testing. Emphasizes caution and notes that Dim Mak involves manipulation, not just striking.

structure_content.chapter_title: Time Delay Effects and Chi Striking Results
structure_content.summary: Explains that Dim Mak strikes can have delayed effects, impacting blood circulation, chi pathways, or major nerves. When striking with chi, results are categorized by force: heavy strikes yield immediate effects, moderate strikes take 3 days, and light strikes manifest in 30 days.
Presents diagrams illustrating the original 36 deadly vital points on both the front and back of the human body, serving as visual aids for point location.

Introduces the 'Redman' chart depicting 36 deadly striking points. It differentiates 'vital points' (e.g., eyes, throat) from 'Dim Mak points' which specifically target glands or organs for penetration. Each point is numerically labeled for subsequent description.

Provides a numbered list detailing 36 specific vital points, anatomically described (e.g., Coronal Suture, Temples, Throat, Armpit, First Lumbar Vertebra, Testicles, Ankles). It stresses the necessity of integrating these points into one's martial arts curriculum and consistent practice for proficiency.

Discusses that original Dim Mak practitioners used various devices. It then outlines numerous hand-based striking methods for attacking vital points, also noting the use of improvised weapons like pens or kubotans.

Details several hand formations and their applications: The Fist Strike (knuckles for penetration), The Vertical Fist (first two/bottom two knuckles, wrist flexing for angle, chi projection), The Knife Hand or Thrusting Fingers (fingers into soft spots, damage adjustment), The Bone Chop (small wrist bone for chopping, effective on neck/limbs), Palm Bone Strike (palm bone for downward/hooking strikes on head/face), Crane Hand Strike (wrist bones for penetrating soft areas, whipping motion), Leopard Paw Strike (versatile, fore knuckles, chi strike to organs/meridians), Knuckle Punch (digging into nerves, grappling use), Middle Finger Fist (penetrating strike for soft areas, better alignment than knuckle punch).

structure_content.chapter_title: Double Point Striking & Triple Point Striking
structure_content.summary: Introduces advanced methods of simultaneously striking multiple points to exponentially increase trauma. It notes this is highly guarded information and includes a chart of double and triple point combinations with their corresponding effects (e.g., paralysis, cardiac arrest, death, internal organ damage).

Provides general guidelines: single point strikes cause pain, paralysis, or knockout. Double point strikes create converging energy, affecting organs. It presents lists of specific double and triple point combinations with their predicted outcomes, ranging from paralysis and knockout to various forms of death, some with delayed effects (e.g., within 3 days, 14 months, 30 days).

Critiques other resources for lacking practical training advice. It emphasizes consistent study of charts, integration of strikes into existing martial arts forms, and an open mind. Suggests creating unique combinations and developing muscle memory through repetitive practice.

Recommends adapting ancient Shaolin Monk shadow boxing, where practitioners visualize fighting imaginary opponents, to Dim Mak. It suggests using training dummies or marking heavy bags with vital points. The ultimate goal is to build 'muscle memory' â€“ subconscious reflexes for striking vital points under stress.

Details a secret, highly effective training method: placing a five-point 'Diamond Point Striking Chart' in a frequently accessed area and routinely striking it with knuckles to build muscle memory. The book concludes by reiterating the dual nature of Dim Mak (healing or harming) and urging ethical use for helping others.

key_concepts.definition: A closely guarded Chinese martial art tradition involving precise strikes to vital points on the body to induce various effects, from pain and paralysis to organ damage or death. It also holds potential for healing.

Specific anatomical locations on the body that, when struck with appropriate force and angle, can cause significant trauma, including bleeding, fainting, increased blood pressure, piercing of major organs/nerve plexuses, temporary numbing, paralysis, or death. These points also have applications in healing.

Internal energy or life force. In Dim Mak, 'chi' is used in conjunction with strikes to enhance their effects, allowing for deeper penetration, delayed results, and targeting of specific organs or meridians. 'Chi manipulating' is a core aspect of higher-level strikes.

The first level of Dim Mak striking, primarily focused on attacking the body's nerves to induce paralysis. This method can be effective even without precise point targeting, as nerves are widely distributed and responsive to various forms of attack.

The second level of Dim Mak striking, which involves targeting blood vessels to seal veins and arteries, leading to blood clots. This can cause organ deterioration, cardiac arrest, or stroke. It often requires internal 'chi striking' and precise timing based on the time of day.

The third and highest level of Dim Mak striking, where the practitioner attacks the Chi Meridians of the body. This involves 'chi manipulating' the bioelectrical fields to alter electromagnetic flow and destroy the body's four levels of energy, potentially causing immediate or delayed death. It requires the ability to 'externalize chi'.

The phenomenon in Dim Mak where the full impact of a strike is not immediate but manifests over a period, ranging from minutes to days or even months. The duration of the delay is influenced by the force of the strike and the application of chi (heavy strike = immediate, moderate = 3 days, light = 30 days).

A training principle emphasizing repetitive practice to 'burn' information into the brain, allowing the body and mind to react instinctively and precisely under stress. It is crucial for effectively executing Dim Mak strikes without conscious thought in a real combat situation.

A practical training tool consisting of five small, pencil-eraser-sized points arranged in a diamond pattern. It is placed in a frequently encountered location (e.g., a doorway) and repeatedly struck with knuckles to rapidly develop muscle memory for vital point targeting.

practical_system.description: The Dim Mak system detailed involves precisely striking vital points on the human body to achieve a range of effects from pain and paralysis to organ damage, cardiac arrest, or death. It categorizes strikes by their target (nerves, blood vessels, chi meridians) and introduces increasingly complex single, double, and triple point striking methods. The integration and externalization of 'chi energy' are presented as crucial for higher-level techniques and delayed effects. Training emphasizes developing 'muscle memory' through structured practice methods.
tools: The practitioner's own hands (in various configurations: fist, vertical fist, knife hand, thrusting fingers, palm bone, crane hand, claw hand, leopard paw, knuckle punch, middle finger fist).
Improvised weapons for point striking (e.g., ballpoint pens, sticks, kubotans).
Training dummies specifically designed and marked with vital points.
Heavy bags equipped with stickers or markings to simulate vital point locations.
Diamond Point Striking Chart (a physical diagram for routine striking practice).
rituals: Dedicated study of vital point charts and anatomical diagrams.
Repetitive practice of various hand striking methods (e.g., Fist, Vertical Fist, Knife Hand, Bone Chop, Leopard Paw, Knuckle Punch) to develop precision and penetration.
Shadow boxing exercises, visualizing strikes against imaginary opponents to integrate vital point targeting into combat scenarios.
Training with marked dummies or heavy bags, applying stickers to denote vital point locations for practical accuracy drills.
Daily routine practice using a 'Diamond Point Striking Chart' (a simple five-point pattern) to build subconscious muscle memory and refine striking consistency.
Implied advanced practices for 'externalizing Chi' for Level Three strikes, likely involving internal energy cultivation and meditation (referenced to other products by the company).

relevant_quotes.text: Dim Mak is one of the most closely guarded secrets in the fighting world. Legends tell stories of the fabled 'Death Touch'.

Scientific Premium Company- USA makes the claim that the information described here are for information purposes only and we accept no responsibility for you using these concepts to hurt, maim or intentionally or unintentionally end a life. It is with that we suggest you get a qualified instructor to teach you in your area.
The real secret to these points is not the death that they can cause, but the health and life you can preserve by using these in the correct manner (See Pressure Points Booklet).
Dim Mak is taken from the Chinese word for 'Death Point Striking' and is considered one of the highest levels in the martial arts.

Many of the points discussed in one chart may be different than one of another. Keep in mind that in order to understand the potency of this technology, Chinese doctors would strike these points on animals to insure that in-fact they worked as they thought they would.

When striking to the points using chi, results can be determined by the following: 1. A heavy strike can cause an immediate effect 2. A moderate strike will produce the effect within 3 days 3. A light strike will produce an effect in 30 days
By doing a double or triple point strike, you increase your ability to cause trauma to the opponent exponentially over just a single strike.
You must burn this information into your brain. This is called muscle memory.
Like a double-edged sword, these concepts can hurt or heal. You are the one that must decide how to use them.

critical_analysis.relevance: This text is highly relevant to esotericism and occultism, particularly within the context of Asian martial arts traditions that integrate vital point striking with internal energy (Chi/Ki). It offers a practical system of combat rooted in traditional Chinese medical and philosophical principles, presenting a 'forbidden' or 'secret' knowledge often associated with esoteric martial arts. The emphasis on Chi, meridians, and delayed effects aligns with esoteric understandings of energy manipulation and occult combat methodologies.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience includes martial artists (from beginner to advanced), self-defense practitioners, students of traditional Chinese medicine or internal arts, and individuals interested in the esoteric applications of pressure points and vital strike methodologies. The text particularly appeals to those seeking advanced or 'secret' knowledge not commonly taught in mainstream martial arts, with explicit disclaimers for ethical and responsible use.
